## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - X1.1 Flare
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-05-31T22:14:29Z
## Message ID: 20240531-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significant flare detected by GOES.

Flare start time: 2024-05-31T21:52Z. 

Flare peak time: 2024-05-31T22:03Z.

Flare intensity: X1.1 class.

Source region: S17E34 (Active Region 13697) (based on SDO imagery).

Increased energetic proton fluxes possible. Updates on this event will be provided when available.

Activity ID: 2024-05-31T21:52:00-FLR-001.

## Notes:

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:
 

Significant flare detected by GOES.  Flare intensity has crossed the threshold of M5.0.

Flare M5.0 crossing time: 2024-05-31T22:01Z. 

Increased energetic proton fluxes possible. Updates on this event will be provided when available.

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CMEs (Psyche)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-05-30T22:35:57Z
## Message ID: 20240530-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Multiple CMEs have been detected as follows:
1: C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-05-30T03:48Z.

Estimated speed: ~561 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 27 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -60/-2 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-05-30T03:48:00-CME-001

2: C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-05-30T09:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~750 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 25 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -78/-3 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-05-30T09:24:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may impact Psyche. The leading edge of the CMEs may reach Psyche at 2024-06-06T15:04Z (plus minus 7 hours). 


Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CMEs: 2024-05-30T03:48:00-CME-001 and 2024-05-30T09:24:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240530_093300_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240530_093300_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif

(b) 5.5 AU outer boundary

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 22, 2024 - May 28, 2024
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-05-29T23:03:30Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2024-05-22T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2024-05-28T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20240529-7D-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate to high level during this reporting period with 1 X-class flare, 12 M-class flares, 1 O-type CME, and 12 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2024-05-23T06:48Z may give NASA missions near Earth a glancing blow at 2024-05-27T03:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) with possible Kp index 2-4 (below minor) (see notification 20240523-AL-001). No clear arrival signature of this CME was detected at L1.

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact the listed locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2024-05-23T04:24Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2024-05-25T19:02Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-05-27T03:00Z (glancing blow), Mars at 2024-05-28T11:30Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240523-AL-002).
2024-05-23T13:25Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2024-05-25T19:02Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-05-27T03:00Z (glancing blow), Mars at 2024-05-28T11:30Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240523-AL-002).
2024-05-24T03:12Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2024-05-26T14:00Z (glancing blow), Mars at 2024-05-29T12:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240524-AL-001).
2024-05-24T20:48Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2024-05-26T17:21Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-05-28T00:00Z (glancing blow), Mars at 2024-05-29T05:56Z (see notification 20240525-AL-001).
2024-05-27T07:23Z   Psyche at 2024-05-31T22:44Z (see notification 20240527-AL-003).
2024-05-28T05:36Z   OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-05-31T08:00Z (glancing blow), Solar Orbiter at 2024-05-31T08:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240528-AL-001).


Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 4.0 for the reporting period.


The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 


The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 


Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this reporting period.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-05-29T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-06-04T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be at moderate to high levels in the outlook period. There are currently seven numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13697 (currently located at S18E57) has produced two X-class flares and several M-class flares at the time of this writing, and will likely continue to exhibit notable flaring activity throughout the outlook period. Active Regions 13691 and 13695 (currently located at N27E08 and N28E21, respectively) have been responsible for a few M-class flares during the reporting period and may continue to exhibit notable flaring activity throughout the outlook period. It is highly suspected that Active Regions 13691 (N27E08) and 13697 (S18E57) are respectively previously numbered Active Regions 13663 and 13664, which were responsible for numerous X-class and M-class flares observed during prior reporting periods. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels during the outlook period. A slight enhancement in geomagnetic activity may be observed on or around 2024-06-01 due to a possible cursory glancing blow from a C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO imagery at 2024-05-29T14:48Z. The possibility of enhancements in geomagnetic activity may increase as Active Regions 13691 (N27E08) and 13697 (S18E57) continue to rotate further onto and across the Earth-facing disk over the course of the outlook period. 

## Notes:

ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Psyche, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-05-29T21:43:36Z
## Message ID: 20240529-AL-005
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-05-29T14:48Z.

Estimated speed: ~812 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 45 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -71/-4 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-05-29T14:48:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Psyche (minor impact).  The leading edge of the CME will reach Psyche at 2024-06-04T20:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may have a cursory glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME might reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-06-01T20:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 2-4 (below minor).
   
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2024-05-29T14:48:00-CME-001):

(a) 2 AU outer boundary
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240529_191000_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240529_191000_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240529_191000_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif

(b) 5.5 AU outer boundary
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240529_191000_5.5_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240529_191000_5.5_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20240529_191000_5.5_ENLIL_CONE_Psyche_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

This CME event (2024-05-29T14:48:00-CME-001) is associated with X1.4 flare from AR13697 (S23E70) with ID 2024-05-29T14:11:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2024-05-29T14:37Z (see notifications 20240529-AL-001, 20240529-AL-002).

2024-05-17T04:17Z   Mars at 2024-05-20T07:52Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-05-19T09:31Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-05-19T00:37Z, and Solar Orbiter at 2024-05-18T21:55Z (see notification 20240517-AL-004).
2024-05-17T12:48Z   Mars at 2024-05-20T07:52Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-05-19T09:31Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-05-19T00:37Z, and Solar Orbiter at 2024-05-18T21:55Z (see notifications 20240517-AL-003 and 20240517-AL-004).
2024-05-17T18:48Z   OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-05-20T10:10Z and Mars at 2024-05-21T18:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240518-AL-003).

2024-05-20T05:36Z   Juno at 2024-05-31T19:50Z and Solar Orbiter at 2024-05-21T06:05Z (see notification 20240520-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 6 during the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 6 occurred during the synoptic periods 2024-05-16T06:00Z-09:00Z and 2024-05-17T18:00Z-21:00Z (see notifications 20240516-AL-002, 20240516-AL-004, and 20240517-AL-006). The first enhancement of geomagnetic activity was likely associated with the interplanetary shock detected at L1 by ACE and DSCOVR at 2024-05-16T04:35Z which may have been associated with a possible transient arrival (see notification 20240516-AL-003). This arrival may have been detected by STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments around 2024-05-16T11:37Z. The second enhancement of geomagnetic activity was likely associated with the interplanetary shock detected at L1 by ACE and DSCOVR at 2024-05-17T12:40Z which was associated with the arrival of the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-05-14T10:09Z (see notification 20240517-AL-002). 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt briefly crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2024-05-15T13:55Z (see notifications 20240515-AL-005 and 20240515-AL-007) and subsided to near background levels by 2024-05-16. This brief elevation of energetic electron flux levels was associated with the combined arrival of the C-type CMEs first seen in SOHO LASCO imagery at 2024-05-08T05:36Z, 2024-05-08T12:24Z, and 2024-05-08T19:12Z detected by ACE at L1 at 2024-05-10T16:36Z during the previous reporting period. This enhancement was also associated with the combined arrival of the O-type CMEs first seen in SOHO LASCO imagery 2024-05-08T22:24Z and 2024-05-09T09:24Z detected at L1 by ACE and DSCOVR at 2024-05-11T09:30Z during the previous reporting period.

The energetic proton fluxes at GOES, SOHO and STEREO A remained above threshold levels at the beginning of the reporting period due to a solar energetic particle event first detected in the previous reporting period at 2024-05-13T12:44Z (see notifications 20240513-AL-006, 20240513-AL-007, 20240513-AL-008,  20240513-AL-009, and 20240513-AL-011). This enhanced particle environment at SOHO, GOES and STEREO A began to subside on 2024-05-16, decreasing below each spacecrafts respective threshold and remaining slightly elevated above background levels. The energetic particle fluxes at all three locations decreased to background levels on 2024-05-18.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate to high this reporting period due to the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt, the solar energetic particle events detected at SOHO, GOES, and STEREO A, and the geomagnetic activity described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-05-22T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-05-28T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor to moderate levels in the outlook period. There are currently six numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13685 (currently located at S12W09) produced an X-class flare and the majority of M-class flares observed during reporting period, and will likely continue to exhibit notable flaring activity throughout the outlook period. It is also possible that previously numbered Active Regions 13663 and 13664, which were responsible for numerous X and M-class flares observed during prior reporting periods, may rotate onto the Earth-facing disk again on or around 2024-05-24 and 2024-05-27, respectively.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A slight enhancement in geomagnetic activity may be observed on or around 2024-05-22 and 2024-05-23 due to possible glancing blow arrivals from the C-type CMEs first visible in SOHO LASCO imagery at 2024-05-19T14:23Z, 2024-05-19T19:09Z, 2024-05-20T20:12Z, and 2024-05-20T21:12Z described above. Additionally, coronal holes currently centered around N40W20 and S35E20 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) may become geoeffective on or around 2024-05-23 and 2024-05-27, respectively.

Estimated opening half-angle: 31 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -13/46 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-05-15T10:36:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Lucy (glancing blow) and STEREO A (glancing blow). The flank of the CME will reach Lucy at 2024-05-21T23:00Z and STEREO A at 2024-05-18T19:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-05-19T04:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 2-3 (below minor).

## Summary:

Solar activity was at very high levels during this reporting period with 12 X-class flares and 80 M-class flares (see list below). There was 1 R-type CME, 8 O-type CMEs, and 14 C-type CMEs (see details below).

Geomagnetic activity reached extreme levels during the reported period, with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) reaching 9. The geomagnetic storm lasted from 2024-05-10T15:00Z to 2024-05-12T06:00Z, with Kp values ranging from 6.67 to 9 (see notifications 20240510-AL-013, 20240510-AL-014, 20240510-AL-015, 20240510-AL-016, 20240511-AL-002, 20240511-AL-003, and 20240511-AL-015). The highest value of Kp=9 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2024-05-10T21:00Z to 2024-05-11T03:00Z and 2024-05-11T09:00Z-2024-05-11T12:00Z (see notifications 20240511-AL-002, 20240511-AL-003, 20240511-AL-015). This extreme geomagnetic storm was associated with an interplanetary shock detected at L1 by ACE and DSCOVR around 2024-05-10T16:36Z (see notification 20240510-AL-010) that was likely caused by the combined arrival of the C-type CMEs first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-05-08T05:36Z, 2024-05-08T12:24Z, and 2024-05-08T19:12Z. This storm may have been further enhanced by an interplanetary shock detected at L1 by ACE and DSCOVR around 2024-05-11T09:30Z and possibly associated with the combined arrival of the O-type CMEs first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-05-08T22:24Z and 2024-05-09T09:24Z (see notification 20240510-AL-017). The combined arrival of these CMEs was also detected by STEREO A at 2024-05-10T14:00Z. These arrivals are still under analysis.

A period of moderate geomagnetic activity with Kp index <= 6 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2024-05-12T21:00Z to 2024-05-13T06:00Z (see notifications 20240513-AL-001, 20240513-AL-002). This geomagnetic storm was associated with an interplanetary shock detected at L1 by ACE and DSCOVR around 2024-05-12T08:57Z that was likely caused by the arrival of the C-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-05-10T07:12Z (see notification 20240510-AL-003). 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux was elevated but below the threshold on 2024-05-13 in association with the above mentioned arrivals of multiple CMEs on 2024-05-10T16:36Z, 2024-05-11T09:30Z and 2024-05-12T08:57Z.

Several solar energetic particle events were detected by SOHO, GOES, and STEREO A during the reporting period. At SOHO, the flux of one or more of the >15.8 MeV protons channels exceeded the threshold of 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-05-10T12:59Z and at GOES the flux of >10 MeV protons exceeded 10 pfu starting at 2024-05-10T13:35Z (see notifications 20240510-AL-004, 20240510-AL-005). At STEREO A, the flux of the 13-100 MeV protons exceeded the threshold of 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-05-10T14:50Z (see notifications 20240510-AL-008, 20240510-AL-009). This solar energetic particle event was likely associated with an X3.9 flare from Active Region 13664 peaking at  2024-05-10T06:54Z  (see notifications 20240510-AL-001, 20240510-AL-002) and an associated O-type CME first detected in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-05-10T07:12Z (see notification 20240510-AL-003), with contributions from numerous other X and M-class flares from the Active Region 13664 starting as early as 2024-05-08. By the start of 2024-05-11 the proton fluxes at GOES and at STEREO A briefly dipped below their respective thresholds while at SOHO such dip was likely obscured by a data gap.

Just hours later, at 2024-05-11T02:10Z, the flux of >100 MeV protons at GOES exceeded the threshold of 1 pfu while the already elevated >10 MeV proton flux again rose above 10 pfu at 2024-05-11T02:10Z (see notifications 20240511-AL-006, 20240511-AL-007). At STEREO A the proton flux rose above its threshold again at 2024-05-11T04:07Z (see notifications 20240511-AL-008, 20240511-AL-013). This second SEP event was associated with an X5.8 flare from Active Region 3664 peaking at  2024-05-11T01:23Z (see notifications 20240511-AL-004, 20240511-AL-005) and an associated O-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2024-05-11T01:36Z (see notifications 20240511-AL-009, 20240511-AL-012). The enhanced particle environment at all three locations decreased below thresholds on 2024-05-12. 

During the third SEP event of the reporting period the >10 MeV proton flux at GOES and the proton fluxes at SOHO and STEREO again exceeded their respective thresholds: the flux at STEREO at 2024-05-13T12:44Z (see notifications 20240513-AL-006, 20240513-AL-007), the >10 MeV proton flux at GOES at 2024-05-13T14:00Z (see notifications 20240513-AL-008,  20240513-AL-009) and the flux at SOHO during the data gap ending at 2024-05-13T18:07Z (see notification 20240513-AL-011). This third SEP event was associated with multiple M-class flares from Active Region 13664 including an M1.2 flare peaking at 2024-05-13T08:20Z, an M1.4 flare with peaking at 2024-05-13T08:29Z, an M4.9 flare peaking at 2024-05-13T09:33Z, and an M6.6 flare peaking at 2024-05-13T09:44Z (see notifications 20240513-AL-003 and 20240513-AL-004). 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been high this reporting period due to the solar energetic particle events detected at SOHO, GOES, and STEREO A and geomagnetic activity described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-05-15T00:00Z ## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-05-21T23:59Z

Solar may remain at high levels throughout the outlook period. There are currently 11 Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13664 was responsible for the vast majority of the X-class and M-class flares during the reporting period before rotating off of the Earth-facing disk on 2024-05-14, and has continued to exhibit high levels of flaring and CME activity while behind the limb. An unnumbered Active Region on the east limb currently around latitude S10 as seen in available EUV imagery produced one X-class flare and two M-class flares during the outlook period and may continue to exhibit notable flaring activity as it rotates onto the Earth-facing disk.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A slight enhancement in geomagnetic activity might be observed on or around 2024-05-17 due to a possible glancing blow from the C-type CME first visible in STEREO COR2 imagery at 2024-05-14T10:09Z.

## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-05-15T14:32:31Z

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2024-05-15T13:55Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the arrival of CME with ID 2024-05-07T03:12:00-CME-001, CME with ID 2024-05-07T05:24:00-CME-001, CME with ID 2024-05-08T05:36:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20240508-AL-012, 20240509-AL-010), CME with ID 2024-05-08T12:24:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20240508-AL-009, 20240509-AL-010), CME with ID 2024-05-08T19:12:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20240509-AL-005, 20240509-AL-010),  CME with ID 2024-05-08T22:24:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20240509-AL-009, 20240509-AL-010), and CME with ID 2024-05-09T09:24:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20240509-AL-006, 20240509-AL-010).

The combined arrival of several of these CMEs was detected by ACE at L1 at 2024-05-10T16:36Z (see notification 20240510-AL-010) followed by another combined arrival of several more of these CMEs detected by ACE and DSCOVR at L1 at 2024-05-11T09:30Z (see notification 20240510-AL-017).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2024-05-15T13:55:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 
These combined CME arrivals are associated with extreme geomagnetic storm with ID 2024-05-10T15:00:00-GST-001 with multiple periods of Kp=9.0 (see notifications 20240510-AL-013, 20240510-AL-014, 20240510-AL-015, 20240510-AL-016, 20240511-AL-002, 20240511-AL-003, and 20240511-AL-015). Simulations indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2024-05-10T18:01Z (see notifications 20240510-AL-011, 20240510-AL-012, and 20240511-AL-001).

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may impact Mars, OSIRIS-APEX and Parker Solar Probe.  The leading edge of the CMEs will reach Mars at 2024-05-17T02:11Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-05-16T06:40Z, and Parker Solar Probe at 2024-05-15T22:24Z (plus minus 7 hours). 


CME parameters are:

1: Start time of the event: 2024-05-14T17:00Z.

(Parameters for this CME have not been updated)

Estimated speed: ~2119 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 37 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 96/3 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-05-14T17:00:00-CME-001


2: Start time of the event: 2024-05-14T17:30Z.

Estimated speed: ~1199 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 38 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 96/2 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-05-14T17:30:00-CME-001

## Summary:

Solar energetic particle event detected by SOHO.  The flux of one or more of the >15.8 MeV protons channels exceeds 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-05-13T18:07Z.

NASA spacecraft at the L1 and near-Earth orbits can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2024-05-13T18:07:00-SEP-002.

## Notes: 
Data gap in SOHO from 2024-05-13T14:27Z - 2024-05-13T18:07Z, with the threshold crossed once data returned at T18:07Z, so the true start time is unknown.

Earlier solar energetic particle event prediction by MODEL: REleASE:SOHO/EPHIN 15.8-39.8 MeV with a 2024-05-13T13:10Z event time (see notification 20240513-AL-005), and by MODEL: REleASE:ACE/EPAM 15.8-39.8 MeV with a 2024-05-13T16:19Z event time (see notification 20240513-AL-010).

Earlier solar energetic particle event was detected by STEREO A at 2024-05-13T12:44Z (see notifications 20240513-AL-006 and 20240513-AL-007) and GOES at 2024-05-13T14:00Z (see notifications 20240513-AL-008 and 20240513-AL-009).

This SEP event (2024-05-13T18:07:00-SEP-002) is associated with multiple M-class flares from Active Region 13664 (S18W80), including an M1.2 flare with ID 2024-05-13T08:06:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2024-05-13T08:20Z, an M1.4 flare with ID 2024-05-13T08:23:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2024-05-13T08:29Z, an M4.9 flare with ID 2024-05-13T08:47:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2024-05-13T09:33Z, and an M6.6 flare with ID 2024-05-13T09:36:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2024-05-13T09:44Z (see notifications 20240513-AL-003 and 20240513-AL-004). Also associated with the CME with ID 2024-05-13T09:12:00-CME-001.

## Message Issue Date: 2024-05-11T14:23:10Z
## Message ID: 20240511-AL-012
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Update on CME with ID 2024-05-11T01:36:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20240511-AL-009). Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Lucy, Mars, Parker Solar Probe, STEREO A, and OSIRIS-APEX (glancing blow). The leading edge of the CME will reach Lucy at 2024-05-14T18:37Z, Mars at 2024-05-13T17:42Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-05-12T05:42Z, STEREO A at 2024-05-12T20:25Z (plus minus 7 hours), and the flank of the CME will reach OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-05-13T04:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-05-13T04:59Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 5-7 (minor to strong).
   

Updated CME parameters are (event remains to O-type):

Start time of the event: 2024-05-11T01:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~1263 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 51 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 51/0 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-05-11T01:36:00-CME-001

## Summary:

Solar energetic particle event detected by GOES.  The flux of > 100 MeV protons exceeds 1 pfu starting at 2024-05-11T02:10Z.

NASA Spacecraft at MEO, GEO and other high-altitude orbits and high-inclination LEO can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2024-05-11T02:10:00-SEP-001.

## Notes: 

This SEP event (2024-05-11T02:10:00-SEP-001) is associated with X5.8 flare from Active Region 3664 (S17W47) with ID 2024-05-11T01:10:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2024-05-11T01:23Z (see notifications 20240511-AL-004, 20240511-AL-005) and an associated partial halo CME that is currently being analyzed.

The flux of > 10 MeV protons had previously exceeded 10 pfu starting at 2024-05-10T13:35Z (SEP event with ID 2024-05-10T13:35:00-SEP-001, see notifications 20240510-AL-004, 20240510-AL-005) in association with numerous M and X-class flares from Active Region 13664 and associated CMEs from 2024-05-08 and 2024-05-09. The > 10 MeV proton flux dipped just below 10 pfu at 2024-05-11T01:10Z and has again risen above the threshold of 10 pfu at 2024-05-11T02:10Z.

## Summary:

Intensifying space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 9 (extreme) during the synoptic period 2024-05-10T21:00Z to 2024-05-11T00:00Z. 

The storm is caused by the Interplanetary Shock with ID 2024-05-10T21:39:00-IPS-001 (see notification 20240510-AL-017) and the earlier Interplanetary Shock with ID 2024-05-10T16:36:00-IPS-001 (see notification 20240510-AL-010) which are associated with the arrivals of CME with ID 2024-05-08T05:36:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20240508-AL-012, 20240509-AL-010), CME with ID 2024-05-08T12:24:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20240508-AL-009, 20240509-AL-010), CME with ID 2024-05-08T22:24:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20240509-AL-009, 20240509-AL-010) and/or possibly CME with ID 2024-05-09T09:24:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20240509-AL-006, 20240509-AL-010).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2024-05-10T15:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes: 
This event is also associated with modeled Magnetopause Crossing with ID 2024-05-10T18:01:00-MPC-001 (see notifications 20240510-AL-011, 20240510-AL-012 and 20240511-AL-001).

## Summary:

Strong compression of the magnetosphere continues. Simulations carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center indicate that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma has been intermittently close to the geosynchronous orbit since 2024-05-10T18:01Z, after the first Interplanetary Shock of today with ID 2024-05-10T16:36:00-IPS-001 (see notifications 20240510-AL-010, 20240510-AL-011, 20240510-AL-012). 

According to the simulations, the magnetopause is currently close to the geosynchronous orbit following the second Interplanetary Shock with ID 2024-05-10T21:39:00-IPS-001 (see notification 20240510-AL-017). 

The activity is associated with the arrival of CME with ID 2024-05-08T05:36:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20240508-AL-012, 20240509-AL-010), CME with ID 2024-05-08T12:24:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20240508-AL-009, 20240509-AL-010), CME with ID 2024-05-08T22:24:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20240509-AL-009, 20240509-AL-010) and/or CME with ID 2024-05-09T09:24:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20240509-AL-006, 20240509-AL-010).

NASA spacecraft at the geosynchronous orbits may be exposed to solar wind plasma and magnetic field conditions.

Activity ID: 2024-05-10T18:01:00-MPC-001.

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-05-08T19:12Z.

Estimated speed: ~828 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 38 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -23/3 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-05-08T19:12:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Psyche (glancing blow), STEREO A, and Lucy (glancing blow).  The leading edge of the CME will reach STEREO A at 2024-05-11T06:45Z, and the flank of the CME may reach Psyche at 2024-05-15T20:00Z and Lucy at 2024-05-14T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-05-11T06:42Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 5-7 (minor to strong).

## Summary:

Solar activity was at high levels during this reporting period with 4 X-class flares, 44 M-class flares, and 17 C-type CMEs (see details below).

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact missions near Earth:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impact (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2024-05-03T02:48Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2024-05-06T06:00Z (glancing blow), Kp index 2-4 (below minor)
                                       (see notification 20240503-AL-003)
                                       The arrival of this CME may have been detected at L1 around 2024-05-05T11:30Z.
2024-05-03T21:17Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2024-05-06T19:00Z (glancing blow), Kp index 3-5 (below minor to minor)
                                       (see notification 20240504-AL-004)                                    
                                       The arrival of this CME was not detected at L1.
2024-05-03T21:28Z   NASA missions near Earth at 2024-05-06T19:00Z (glancing blow), Kp index 3-5 (below minor to minor)
                                       (see notification 20240504-AL-004)                                    
                                       The arrival of this CME was not detected at L1.

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact the listed locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2024-05-01T06:36Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2024-05-03T03:40Z, Lucy at 2024-05-07T03:00Z (glancing blow), Mars at 2024-05-05T16:00Z (glancing blow), OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-05-04T18:00Z (glancing blow), and STEREO A at 2024-05-04T20:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240501-AL-002). 
2024-05-02T10:36Z    OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-05-06T02:13Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2024-05-04T16:26Z, Mars at 2024-05-07T01:00Z (glancing blow).
2024-05-03T02:48Z    STEREO A at 2024-05-06T08:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240503-AL-003). 
2024-05-03T21:17Z    STEREO A at 2024-05-06T18:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240504-AL-004). 
2024-05-03T21:28Z    STEREO A at 2024-05-06T18:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240504-AL-004).  

Note: CME analyses from 2024-05-04 and 2024-05-05 were affected by a real-time coronagraph data outage.  Some CME parameters from these dates were not simulated due to simulation constraints.

Geomagnetic activity was at strong levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6.67 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=6.67 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2024-05-02T15:00Z-21:00Z (see notifications 20240502-AL-004, 20240502-AL-005, 20240502-AL-006). This strong enhancement of geomagnetic activity was associated with the interplanetary shock detected at L1 by ACE and DSCOVR around 2024-05-02T07:46Z (see notification 20240502-AL-001) which may be associated with a coronal hole high speed stream and potentially embedded glancing blow from a CME. The arrival of the coronal hole high speed stream was also detected by STEREO A on 2024-05-02.

Additionally, geomagnetic activity reached Kp=5 during the synoptic period of 2024-05-06T00:00Z-03:00Z. This minor enhancement of geomagnetic activity was associated with the interplanetary shock detected at L1 by ACE and DSCOVR around 2024-05-05T11:30Z which is associated with a possible glancing blow from the C-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO imagery at 2024-05-03T02:48Z (see notification 20240503-AL-003) followed by a coronal hole high speed stream starting on 2024-05-06.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this reporting period due to the geomagnetic activity described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-05-08T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-05-14T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between moderate and high levels throughout the outlook period. There are currently six active regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Regions 13663 (N25W68) and 13664 (S20W20) were responsible for 40 of the M-class flares and all of the X-class flares during the reporting period. Active Region 13664 is expected to continue moderate to high levels of flaring activity throughout the outlook period. Active Region 13663 is expected to rotate off of the Earth-facing disk on 2024-05-10, but is likely to still produce significant flares in the next couple of days. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low to strong levels during the outlook period. Enhanced geomagnetic activity is expected starting on 2024-05-10 through 2024-05-11 due to the anticipated combined arrival of today's C-type halo CME first seen in SOHO LASCO imagery at 2024-05-08T05:36Z associated with the X1.0 class flare from Active Region 13664 and the C-type halo CME first seen in SOHO LASCO imagery at 2024-05-08T12:24Z associated with the M8.6 class flare from Active Region 13664. Further enhancement of geomagnetic activity is possible starting on 2024-05-12 from four coronal holes seen currently on the Earth-facing disk centered near (N07E27), (S35E10), (N25E05), and (N17W14).

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-05-08T12:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~776 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 45 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 3/-5 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-05-08T12:24:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Lucy, STEREO A, and Parker Solar Probe (glancing blow).  The leading edge of the CME will reach Lucy at 2024-05-13T03:59Z, STEREO A at 2024-05-10T20:45Z, and flank of the CME will reach Parker Solar Probe at 2024-05-10T10:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-05-11T01:39Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 5-7 (minor to strong).

## Summary:

Significant interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR at L1 at 2024-05-02T07:46Z. 

The shock may be caused by a transient CME arrival and/or a coronal hole high speed stream. Magnetospheric compression and geomagnetic storm may be expected. This arrival signature is still developing and analysis is ongoing.

Activity ID: 2024-05-02T07:46:00-IPS-001.

## Notes:

An eruption near disk center was observed from Active Region 13659 (S14W10) staring around 2024-04-29T09:12Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 191, 193, 304 imagery which may have produced an Earth-directed CME that was difficult to detect in coronagraph imagery. It is possible this eruption is related to a CME that may have caused this interplanetary shock. Analysis is ongoing and updates will be provided when available.

## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 24, 2024 - April 30, 2024
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-05-01T21:19:02Z

## Report Coverage End Date: 2024-04-30T23:59Z

## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate to high levels during this reporting period with 19 M-class flares, 1 O-type CME, and 5 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact the listed locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2024-04-25T10:48Z    Psyche at 2024-04-30T18:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240425-AL-001).
2024-04-26T00:24Z    Psyche at 2024-05-02T00:00Z (minor impact) (see notification 20240426-AL-001).
2024-04-27T23:12Z    Psyche at 2024-05-03T00:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240429-AL-001).
2024-04-30T02:36Z    OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-05-04T00:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240430-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 5.33 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5.33 occurred during the synoptic period 2024-04-26T15:00Z-18:00Z. This minor geomagnetic activity was associated with the glancing blow of one or more CMEs detected at L1 by ACE and DSCOVR as early as 2024-04-26T00:17Z, which may be associated with S-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-04-23T09:12Z and the S-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-04-24T01:48Z.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt briefly crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2024-04-24T15:45Z (see notifications 20240424-AL-001 and 20240424-AL-002) and again on 2024-04-25, but subsided to near background levels by 2024-04-26. This brief elevation of energetic electron flux levels was associated with the arrival of the C-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-04-15T06:48Z two reporting periods ago (see notifications 20240415-AL-002 and 20240417-AL-001).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this reporting period due to the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-05-01T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-05-07T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between moderate to high levels in the outlook period. Currently, there are six numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13654 (S07W75) has produced several M-class flares towards the end of the reporting period and will likely continue to exhibit notable flaring activity as it rotates off the Earth-facing disk on or around 2024-05-03.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. An ongoing enhancement in the solar wind initially detected by ACE and DSCOVR at 2024-04-30T11:30Z could result in slightly elevated geomagnetic activity during the beginning of the outlook period. A coronal hole currently centered around N13W05 spanning longitudes from E07 to W18 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) may become geoeffective on or around 2024-05-03. A fainter coronal hole structure currently centered around S35W01 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) may become geoeffective on or around 2024-05-05. Additionally, a third coronal hole currently centered around S10E18 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) may become geoeffective on or around 2024-05-07.
